Graphical abstract A series of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 systems have been prepared and characterized by one-pass temperature-programmed desorption of CO2, NH3 and H2O, FTIR spectroscopy with adsorbed pyridine and CO2, temperature programmed surface reaction of ethanol and isopropanol, and reaction of isopropanol conversion. Effect of MgO:SiO2 ratio in the catalysts on catalytic performance in 1,3-butadiene production from aqueous ethanol have been investigated. The results indicate that hydrophilicity of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 are determined by MgO:SiO2 ratio, and chemisorption of water occurs preferably on Mg-containing sites. The presence of water in the initial ethanol leads to a decrease in formation of the CC coupling products. The hydrated sites formed in the interface of magnesia and silica remain active in the CC coupling reaction even in the presence of water. 1,3-Butadiene selectivity >60 % in the conversion of aqueous ethanol (80 vol%) is achieved in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts with the ratio of MgO:SiO2 = (1:1) and (3:1). Keywords Aqueous ethanol 1,3-Butadiene ZnO/MgO-SiO2 H2O effect 1 Introduction The development of large-volume chemical processes based on bio-raw materials to replace the processes based on fossil raw materials is considered as one of the important tasks of sustainable chemistry. The creation and improvement of CC coupling catalytic processes based on bio-alcohols is a very important direction in this field of study [1,2]. One such process is the production of 1,3-butadiene (BD) from bioethanol (ethanol-to-butadiene process, ETB-process) [3–5]. According to the recent reviews [6–9], the scheme of ethanol conversion into BD by Lebedev method involves the following reactions: i) dehydrogenation of ethanol (EtOH) to acetaldehyde, ii) aldol-crotonic condensation of acetaldehyde to produce crotonaldehyde, iii) Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verlei (MPV) reduction of crotonaldehyde by EtOH to crotyl alcohol, iv) dehydration of crotyl alcohol to produce BD. The relations between dehydrogenating and acid-base characteristics of the catalyst determine its effectivity in the ETB process. For implementation of the ETB process in industry the effect of water vapor in the feed mixture should be studied in detail [7,8], as it would help predict the viability of using more affordable concentrated (50–80 %) aqueous ethanol, which can be obtained by rapid membrane filtration of a fermentation broth [10,11]. Back in the early 1940s, Lebedev with colleagues were showed a decrease in the yield indices of BD and ethylene with increasing the water content of an ethanol-water feed mixture, while the yield of acetaldehyde increases [12]. In the recent studies on the ETB process with ethanol-water mixture as a feed in the presence of the catalysts of different oxide and zeolite nature (Lebedev industrial catalyst [12], Zn-Al [13], Mg-Si [14], Zn-Zr-Si [15], Zn-La-Zr-Si [16–18], Zn-Hf-Si [19], Ta(Zr)-BEA zeolites [17,20]) BD selectivity decreases with increasing water fraction in the input stream, while the selectivity to acetaldehyde and EtOH dehydration products (ethylene + diethyl ether (DEE)) increases. In the conversion of EtOH–AA–H2O mixture in the presence of MgO–SiO2 [21] or ZnO–ZrO2–SiO2 [22] an increase in the concentration of water vapor of the reaction mixture (RM) leads to decrease in the yield of both BD and ethylene. Based on Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopic results of adsorbed pyridine, Velasquez Ochoa et al. for MgO-SiO2 (at 323 K) [14] and later González et al. for ZnO-HfO2/SiO2 (at 653 K) [19] showed a possibility of the formation of a small number of Brönsted acid sites (BAS) in the presence of water vapor in the feed, that explained the increase in ethylene selectivity. Based on in situ FTIR spectroscopic results of ethanol (or acetone) and H2O co-adsorption, H2O was found to not significantly affect EtOH dehydrogenation in the conversion of ethanol-aqueous mixtures in the presence of Zn-La-Zr-Si oxide catalysts. At the reaction temperatures of 573−673 K H2O blocks Lewis acid sites (LAS), which are active sites of aldol condensation of acetaldehyde, it is a key step of the ETB process. This is consistent with the catalytic results obtained: BD selectivity decreases and acetaldehyde selectivity increases with increasing water content in the ethanol-water mixture [16]. However, there is no complete idea of the water vapor effect on the ETB process, and this issue being important in various aspects remains open. Catalysts based on MgO-SiO2 system including those doped with copper, zinc and silver are objects of study in the ETB process most frequently [8,23,32,24–31]. The activity of such catalysts largely depends on the MgO:SiO2 ratio, which affects acid-base characteristics of the catalyst surface. The introduction of metallic (Cu, Ag, Au) and oxide (ZnO, Ga2O3, In2O3) promoters of ethanol dehydrogenation into MgO-SiO2 systems contributes to increase in their activity and BD selectivity in the ETB process [27,30,33–38]. In particular, in our previous work, the relationship between the acid characteristics and catalytic properties of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 was showed [36]. The novelty of this work lies in the assessment of the catalytic behavior of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 systems when using ethanol-water mixtures in the ETB process. The purpose is to study the effect of acid-base characteristics of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 surface on its catalytic properties in the conversion of aqueous ethanol into 1,3-butadiene. This is aimed at a deeper understanding of the H2O effect on the three oxide catalyst properties in the process of BD obtaining from ethanol-water mixtures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The ZnO/MgO, ZnO/SiO2 and ZnO/MgO–SiO2 catalytic systems were prepared by impregnation of magnesium oxide, silica gel and MgO–SiO2 mixtures, respectively, with aqueous solutions of zinc acetate. The obtained samples were dried (393 K, 2 h) and calcined at (773 K, 3 h). Used MgO–SiO2 systems with different MgO:SiO2 ratio were prepared by mixing pre-milled components (fraction of <0.1 mm), namely commercial silica gel (283 m2 g−1) with commercial magnesium oxide (118 m2 g−1), followed by wet-kneading procedure, drying (393 K, 2 h) and calcination (773 K, 3 h). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The study of acid-base characteristics of the samples were performed by one-pass temperature-programmed desorption (OPTPD) of CO2 and NH3 controlled by two mass spectrometers. The experiment was carried out on an ultra-high-vacuum (UHV) installation of the “black chamber” type [39], which allows complex researches of adsorption-desorption processes on a solid surface to be made in situ. The work space of a stainless steel UHV chamber is surrounded by a double-walled jacket, which cooled with liquid nitrogen. The inner walls of this jacket facing the UHV chamber are covered with a titanium film. All this eliminates the distorting effect of secondary processes on the walls of the vacuum chamber and allows single-flight regime detection of desorbed particles from the sample surface. Desorption molecules of CO2 and NH3 from the samples controlled by the time-of-flight mass spectrometer (MSX-3-PC “Electron”, Ukraine) and monopole mass spectrometer (MX7304A-PC “Selmi”, Ukraine). A distance between the sample and the mass spectrometry detector is 0.5 cm. Before adsorption of the probe molecules, the samples with a weight of 20 mg were annealed in a vacuum (a chamber pressure of 10−7 Pa) at 773 K for 1 h, and then cooled to room temperature. Adsorption of the probe molecules was carried out using CO2 and gaseous solution of NH3 in Ar for 12 h. The following desorption procedure was carried out with a heating rate of 0.3 K/sec. The adsorption/desorption experiments of water vapor (H2O-OPTPD), CO2 after H2O pre-adsorption (CO2/H2O-OPTPD), and NH3 after H2O pre-adsorption (NH3/H2O-OPTPD) were performed in the same way. After activation of the sample surface by an annealing in a vacuum (a chamber pressure of 10−7 Pa) at 773 K, the adsorption of H2O was carried out using water vapor at room temperature for 2 h. Before adsorption of CO2 after H2O pre-adsorption, residual and physically adsorbed H2O molecules were removed by vacuuming. The adsorption of CO2 was carried out at room temperature for 12 h with following annealing in a vacuum at 423 K to remove residual and physically adsorbed species. Before adsorption of NH3 after H2O pre-adsorption, residual and physically adsorbed H2O molecules were removed by vacuuming at 423 K, leaving at the surface only chemisorbed H2O molecules. The adsorption of NH3 was carried out at room temperature for 12 h with following remove residual and physically adsorbed species. The following H2O-OPTPD and CO2/H2O-OPTPD procedures were carried out with a heating rate of 0.3 K/sec. NH3/H2O-OPTPD procedures were carried out with a heating rate of 0.15 K/sec. The experiments of temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of ethanol and isopropanol were also performed on the UHV installation of the “black chamber” type and controlled by the time-of-flight mass spectrometer (MSX-3-PC “Electron”, Ukraine) and monopole mass spectrometer (MX7304A-PC “Selmi”, Ukraine). After the preliminary treatment (10−7 Pa, 773 K, 1 h), the samples were contacted with ethanol (96 and 80 vol%) and isopropanol at room temperature for 1 h, then temperature-programmed heating (a rate of 0.15 K/sec) simultaneously with mass spectrometric analysis of the desorption products were performed. The reaction products of ethanol-TPSR were analyzed with the following mass-to-charge (m/z) signals: 2 for H2, 18 for H2O, 26 for C2H4, 44 for C2H4O, 45 for C2H6O, 54 for C4H6, 57 for C4H8O, and 70 for C4H6O. The products of isopropanol-TPSR were identified with m/z values: 41 for C3H6, 43 and 58 for C3H6O (acetone), 45 for C3H8O (isopropanol), 55 and 83 for C6H10O (mesityl oxide), 82 for C9H14O (isophorone). The deconvolution of OPTPD profiles was performed in the Origin program. Carbon balance was calculated as total carbon amount in the analyzed products, divided by the initial total amount of carbon, and it was generally better than 95 %. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Acid-base characteristics of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts Fig. 1 presents CO2-OPTPD and NH3-OPTPD profiles of the studied two- (ZnO/MgO, ZnO/SiO2) and three- (ZnO/MgO-SiO2) component catalytic systems. The acid-base characteristics of the samples, namely acidity/basicity and activation energy of the probe molecule desorption (Ea ), have been calculated based on the deconvoluted OPTPD profiles for each peak separately (see ESI, Figs. S1 and S2) and listed in Table 1 . There are weak (<100 kJ mol−1), medium strength (100–120 kJ mol−1) and strong (100–120 kJ mol−1) acid/base sites. The ZnO/MgO sample is characterized by the highest total basicity. In the case of the ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system, the number of medium and strong base sites decreases as the MgO content decreases (Table 1). The nonlinear dependence of the number and strength of the base sites on the magnesium content in the system can be attributed to the different nature/structure of the sites. Lewis base sites (LBS) could be formed by Mg-O pairs with different coordination numbers at lattice points assigning a particular geometry and Brönsted base sites (BBS) could be formed as [Mg-O(H)-Mg] and [Mg-O-Mg(OH)] surface structures [24,27]. Moreover, in the procedure for the preparation of MgO-SiO2 by wet kneading of the components, a part of base sites of the hydrated surface of magnesium oxide can interact with silica, resulting in the formation of Lewis acid sites [Mg-O-Si] [6,43,44]. Thus, the defects and, accordingly, new base sites, in particular [Mg-O(H)-Si], are formed on the surface of magnesium oxide [24,45,46]. The ZnO/SiO2 sample is characterized by the lowest total basicity, the base sites on the surface of which are due to the presence of bulk ZnO in the composition. The total basicity of ZnO/SiO2 is 20 times lower than that of ZnO/MgO. Therefore, the high basicity of ZnO/MgO and ZnO/MgO-SiO2 systems is resulted from magnesium oxide. According to NH3-OPTPD data (Fig. 1B, Table 1), ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) sample is characterized by the highest total acidity. With an increase/decrease in the MgO:SiO2 ratio, the total acidity of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 decreases. Meanwhile, the values for the two-component catalytic systems are lower than those for the three-component ones. Since the acidity of ZnO/MgO is lower than those for ZnO/MgO-SiO2 samples and ZnO/SiO2, silica can be assumed to take part in the formation of acid sites on the surface of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system. On the ZnO/SiO2 surface, acid sites can be formed only by zinc cations. High values of total acidity for ZnO/MgO-SiO2 samples in comparison with ZnO/SiO2 may indicate that on the surface of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 there are acid sites formed by both Mg- and Zn-containing species. Comparison of the acidity values of the studied samples and the activation energy E of the probe molecule (NH3) desorption reveals both ZnO and MgO to be involved in the formation of acid sites of different strength. However, a greater number of strong acid sites are formed with the participation of magnesium oxide. FTIR spectra of adsorbed pyridine for the samples under study are shown in Fig. 2 . Analysis of the spectra indicates the presence of Lewis acid sites (LAS) of various nature on the surface of two- and three-component catalytic systems, namely [Zn-O-Si] (1453 cm−1) [30,36], [Mg-O-Si] (1449 cm−1) [22,24,37] and weak acid sites of magnesium oxide (1439 cm−1) [30,38,39]. The absorption band at 1446 cm−1 can be attributed to weakly bound pyridine with hydroxyl groups on the surface [27,47]. The intensity of these absorption bands and, accordingly, the number of acid sites of a certain nature is determined by the quantitative composition of ZnO/MgO-SiO2, in particular, by the MgO:SiO2 ratio. The amount of LAS [Zn-O-Si] increases with an increase in the amount of silica in ZnO/MgO-SiO2, as indicated by an increase in the intensity of the band at 1453 cm−1. The FTIR spectrum of ZnO/SiO2 sample exhibits the most intensive absorption band at 1453 cm−1. The highest intensity of the absorption band attributed to LAS [Mg-O-Si] is observed for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) sample, while the intensity of the absorption band attributed to OH groups is low. On the contrary, the intensity of the absorption band at 1446 cm−1 is higher than that at 1449 cm−1 for the samples with the ratio of MgO:SiO2 = (3:1) and (1:3). The FTIR spectrum of ZnO/MgO sample shows low-intensity band in the absorption region of stretching vibrations of pyridine coordinated to the LAS of magnesium oxide (1439 cm−1). Thus, ZnO/MgO is characterized by the highest basicity, the number of medium and strong base sites of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system decreases as the MgO content decreases. The tendency of acidity change in the series of the studied samples is different: the acidity of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system decreases with an increase/decrease in the MgO:SiO2 ratio. On the surface of two- and three-component catalytic systems, there are Lewis acid sites of various nature: [Zn-O-Si], [Mg-O-Si] and weak acid sites of magnesium oxide (Mg2+). 3.2 Catalytic properties of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 samples in ethanol-water mixture conversion Table 2 shows the indices of ethanol-water mixture conversion over the studied two- (ZnO/MgO, ZnO/SiO2) and three-component (ZnO/MgO-SiO2) catalytic systems. In the presence of three-component catalysts, ethanol conversion and the selectivity of BD formation exceed those for two-component ones. At the same time, the indices of ethanol conversion in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:3) and ZnO/SiO2 are comparable, and BD selectivity is twice as high over the first sample. The lowest indices of the ETB process are achieved in the presence of ZnO/MgO. It can be concluded that BD formation during the conversion of an ethanol-water mixture occurs more selectively on active sites formed by Zn2+ and Mg2+ with SiO2. Similar tendencies in the change in the ETB process indices were observed during the conversion of rectified ethanol over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts (ESI, Fig. S3). The higher MgO content in ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst increases the selectivity of BD formation from the ethanol-water mixture. Meanwhile, the highest values of ethanol conversion (44.8 % at T =698 K) and BD yield (25.2 %) are achieved over ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) catalyst, which is characterized by the largest number of surface active sites, in particular LAS [Mg-O-Si] formed as interfacial chemical bonds in binary MgO-SiO2 system [48,49]. The similar volcano-shaped trend of BD yield with a maximum value for MgO:SiO2 = 1:1 was observed over MgO-SiO2 systems by Chung et al. [50]. By changing the selectivity of acetaldehyde formation, ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts with different ratios of MgO:SiO2 are arranged in the following sequence: (1:3) > (3:1) > (1:1). The selectivity of the formation of ethanol dehydration by-products (ethylene, DEE) is higher in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:3) catalyst and decreases with increasing the MgO content in the catalyst. Shylesh et al. [35] for Au/MgO-SiO2 catalysts and Da Ros et al. [51] for Zr,Zn-containing MgO/SiO2 systems prepared by co-precipitation showed a similar effect of MgO:SiO2 ratio on the product selectivity during the ETB process. Fig. 3 shows the achieved yields of BD, acetaldehyde, and ethylene + DEE during the conversion of 96 vol% ethanol and an ethanol-water mixture (80 vol% ethanol) in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts with different ratios of MgO:SiO2, as well as ZnO/MgO and ZnO/SiO2. The corresponding values of ethanol conversion and product selectivity are shown in ESI, Fig. S3. These data make it possible to evaluate the unfavorable effect of water in the composition of the initial mixture on the process indices. An increase in the water content in the initial reaction mixture from 4 to 20 vol% leads to a significant decrease in BD yield over all catalyst samples under study (Fig. 3). In the presence of two-component oxide catalysts, BD yield declines due to a decrease in both ethanol conversion and BD selectivity (Fig. S3), but to varying degrees: by an order of magnitude for ZnO/MgO and ∼3 times for ZnO/SiO2. In the presence of three-component system (ZnO/MgO-SiO2), the decrease of BD yield is preferably conditioned by a decrease in ethanol conversion, rather than BD selectivity. The relative decrease in BD yield depends on the MgO content in the catalyst composition. For ZnO/MgO-SiO2(3:1) catalyst, BD yield is halved; for the catalysts with a lower MgO content, it is reduced by more than 2.5 times. Meanwhile, an inverse dependence of the yield of acetaldehyde and ethanol dehydration products on the MgO:SiO2 ratio in the catalyst is observed; the yield of these products sharply decreases for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(3:1). In the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:3) the yield of dehydration products is twice as high during the conversion of 80 vol% ethanol-water mixture as during the conversion of 96 vol% ethanol. Herewith, for all ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst samples, the selectivity to ethanol dehydration products during the conversion of the ethanol-water mixture is higher than during the conversion of rectified ethanol. Velasquez Ochoa et al. [14] showed a decrease in ethanol conversion (54 % → 23 %) and BD selectivity (27.5 % → 18 %) with the feed change from 2 mol% ethanol in N2 to 2 mol% ethanol +0.5 mol% H2O in N2 during the ETB process over MgO-SiO2 catalyst. Meanwhile, the selectivity to acetaldehyde and ethylene increased. Similar changes in the ethanol conversion and product selectivity were observed for a mixed Hf-Zn catalyst containing Hf/SiO2 and zinc-silicate hemimorphite by Cabello González et al. [19] and for Zn-La-Zr-Si oxide catalyst by Larina et al. [16]. The above mentioned works explained the unfavorable effect of water by the adsorption of H2O molecules on the LASs being active in aldol condensation of acetaldehyde. With an increase in temperature of the ETB process with 80 vol% ethanol from 648 to 698 K (Table 2), the yield of BD and ethylene increases in the presence of three-component systems, and the yield of acetaldehyde decreases. Such a change in the product content (in particular, ethylene and acetaldehyde) is consistent with thermodynamics of the key steps (reactions) of the ETB process: with an increase in temperature, ethanol dehydration becomes a more preferable reaction than its dehydrogenation [52]. When comparing the values of ethanol conversion and BD selectivity during ETB process with 96 and 80 vol% ethanol over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst with an increase in temperature (ESI, Fig. S4), it follows that high temperature partially counteracts the influence of water on ethanol-to-butadiene conversion. This is in line with the results obtained for Zn-La-Zr-Si [16] and Zn-Hf-Si [19] oxide catalysts. Moreover, the selectivity to other products during the ETB process over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst is lower when 80 vol% ethanol is used as the feed than 96 vol% ethanol (Fig. S4). Therefore, the adsorption of H2O on acid-base sites of the catalyst surface decreases the probability of occurrence of side condensation reactions through which heavy products are formed, as noted for other catalysts [17,19]. In the case of rerunning of the ETB process with different feeds (96 and 80 vol% ethanol) in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system after intermediate calcination in airflow at 773 K, the process performance reaches again initial levels (under stationary conditions). This indicates the reversibility of the unfavorable effect of water on active sites of the catalyst. At the same time, high selectivity of the ETB process in terms of BD (>60 %) is retained over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts with a ratio of MgO:SiO2 = (1:1) and (3:1) even when the ethanol-water mixture (80 vol% ethanol) is used as a feed. 3.3 Water vapor effect on functional properties of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts As was noted in Experimental, acid-base properties of the catalysts and their ability to promote alcohol dehydration and dehydrogenation were evaluated using the reaction of isopropanol conversion. Isopropanol tends to dehydrate to propylene over surface acid site, and dehydrogenate to form acetone on surface base site. Fig. 4 A shows the formation rates of propylene and acetone versus time on stream in isopropanol conversion reaction over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 (1:1) catalyst. To evaluate water vapor effect on functional properties of the catalyst, the reaction has been studied with and without H2O in the feed. The formation rates of both products (propylene and acetone) change with time on stream. The propylene one rises slightly at first 50 min and then slowly decreases, wherein the acetone one declines drastically and become quite stable at time of stream of 180 min. The presence of H2O in the feed lead to decrease the formation rates of both propylene and acetone, herewith the tendency of change versus time on stream is saved. Thus, the quantity of both dehydrogenation and dehydration sites of the ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) sample considerably decrease after H2O addition in the feed during isopropanol conversion reaction. Fig. 4B shows the signals of the reagent and reaction products in the isopropanol-TPSR over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 (1:1). The isopropanol-TPSR curves have two regions with desorption maxima at 350−450 K and above 473 K. There are the signals of the products of isopropanol conversion over dehydrogenation and dehydration sites, namely acetone and propylene [30]. The signals of mesityl oxide and isophorone are detected too. The formation of such products is possible as a result of the condensation of acetone into diacetone alcohol with further dehydration (to produce mesityl oxide) and the condensation of mesityl oxide with acetone (to produce isophorone). Since for the formation of mesityl oxide from isopropanol, the required sequence of reactions includes dehydrogenation, condensation and dehydration, strong basic sites of MgO are needed for obtaining mesityl oxide and then isophorone. However, these sites are deactivated during the reaction (at high values of time-on-stream), as noted earlier by Di Cosimo et al. [53]. It can be assumed that the decrease in the formation of acetone with time (Fig. 4A) results from the partial deactivation of strong basic sites on MgO surface. To evaluate the hydrophilic character of catalyst surface (water retention capacity), one-pass temperature-programmed desorption of water vapor (H2O-OPTPD) is often used (H2O as a probe molecule for acid sites on catalyst surface). During the chemisorption of water on the surface of oxide system, there are the formation of a strong adsorption bond between the oxygen atom of H2O and a cation site of the surface (LAS), and a strong hydrogen-bonding interaction with a surface oxygen anion (LBS) [54,55]. Fig. 5 shows H2O-OPTPD profiles of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts. The most intensive desorption peaks for all studied samples are observed in low-temperature region with a maximum at 360−380 K. In high-temperature region (above 450 K), the shape of H2O desorption peaks changes from sample to sample, and their intensity (which is characterized by the area under the curve) decreases as the MgO content in the catalyst decreases. The characteristics of the samples, namely water retention capacity and activation energy of the probe molecule (H2O) desorption (E), have been calculated based on the deconvoluted H2O-OPTPD profiles for each peak separately (see ESI, Fig. S5) and listed in Table 3 . The quantity of hydrophilic sites of the surface is estimated by total water retention capacity, and the strength of the sites is estimated by activation energy of desorption. There are weak (<100 kJ mol−1), medium strength (100–120 kJ mol−1) and strong (100–120 kJ mol−1) hydrophilic sites. The mentioned characteristics depend on the MgO content in ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system. ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) is characterized by the largest number of hydrophilic surface sites, and ZnO/MgO-SiO2(3:1) contains almost half of them (Table 3). Meanwhile, the number of weak sites (E < 100 kJ mol−1), on which physical adsorption of water occurs, changes insignificantly, and the number of strong sites (E ≥ 120 kJ mol−1) decreases by about three times. For the two-component system ZnO/MgO, the relative number of the sites with Е ≥ 120 kJ mol−1 is comparable to the value for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(3:1); at the same time, weak sites (Е <100 kJ mol−1) are half of the number. For ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:3), the relative number of the sites with Е ≥ 120 kJ mol−1 is an order of magnitude lower than for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(3:1), while the number of the sites with Е = 100−120 kJ mol−1 for these samples is comparable. For ZnO/SiO2, the number of hydrophilic sites is more than half as compared to that for MgO-containing samples. Therefore, the adsorption of water can be assumed to preferably occur on Mg-containing sites of the surface. The change in total water retention capacity depending on the MgO:SiO2 ratio in ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system (Table 3) is similar to the change in acidity (according to NH3-OPTPD results, Table 1). This may indicate the preferred adsorption of water molecules by Lewis acid sites. The high value of the relative water retention capacity for ZnO/MgO sample, especially for the sites with E ≥ 120 kJ mol−1, probably indicates the chemisorption of water molecules by the surface of magnesium oxide and the formation of [Mg-O(H)-Mg] or [MgOMgOH] sites. According to the data shown in Fig. 3 for ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst, the relative decrease in BD yield during the conversion of an ethanol-water mixture (80 vol% ethanol) compared to 96 vol% ethanol increases with a decrease in the MgO content in the composition, and ZnO/MgO sample is not active in the formation of BD (AA prevails in the reaction products). The sites [Mg-O(H)-Mg] and [MgOMgOH] on the hydrated surface of individual magnesium oxide are less active in CC coupling reaction, but basic hydroxyl groups are suitable for dehydrogenation [35]. It can be assumed that hydrated sites formed with the participation of magnesium and silicon oxides remain active in CC-coupling reaction even in the presence of water in the reaction mixture. However, according to H2O-OPTPD results, the maximum temperature of water desorption from the surface of the studied systems is 648 K. Since the ETB process is carried out at higher temperatures, the effect of water on the ETB process indices can be concluded to result from the competitive adsorption of water, ethanol and intermediate reaction products on active sites of the catalyst surface. To assess an effect of the water adsorption on the acid characteristics of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst, adsorption/desorption experiments of NH3 was carried out after H2O pre-adsorption. Fig. 6 presents NH3/H2O-OPTPD profiles of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 samples with a different MgO:SiO2 ratio. 1 1 We are aware that such approach of a study and interpretation of NH3/H2O-OPTPD profiles is rather evaluative, since ammonia dissolves in water. And it is difficult to separate NH3 adsorbed on the hydrated acid sites and NH3 chemically bonded to the water chemisorbed onto magnesium oxide and silica. ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) is characterized by the highest total retention capacity of NH3 and H2O both in case of their sequential adsorption (ESI, Table S1) and individual adsorption (Tables 1 and 3). The change in total NH3 retention capacity after H2O pre-adsorption, depending on the MgO:SiO2 ratio in ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system, is similar to the change in acidity (according to NH3-OPTPD results). Moreover, the values of total NH3 retention capacity after H2O pre-adsorption for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(3:1) and ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:3) samples vis-à-vis ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) are higher than the values of total acidity for these samples. It can be caused by the interaction of ammonia with a hydrated surface of MgO and silica. The higher MgO content in ZnO/MgO-SiO2 samples, the higher temperature of NH3 desorption maximum in both NH3/H2O-OPTPD (Fig. 6A) and NH3-OPTPD (Fig. 1B) profiles. Meanwhile, the higher temperatures of the NH3 desorption maxima are observed in NH3/H2O-OPTPD profiles, as opposed to NH3-OPTPD ones (Table 1 and ESI, Table S1). Therefore, there is a change in the acid characteristics of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 surface upon the water adsorption. Fig. 6B shows the signals of H2O molecules chemisorbed on the surface of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 samples and desorbed during NH3/H2O-OPTPD. To ensure only chemisorbed H2O molecules to be remained on the surface before the adsorption of NH3, the samples were evacuated at 423 K. For the sample with MgO:SiO2 ratio of (3:1), the value of total H2O retention capacity is comparable to the ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) one, and for the sample with MgO:SiO2 ratio of (1:3), it is much lower (ESI, Table S1). However, the temperature of H2O desorption maxima is about 525 K for all samples. The proximity of temperatures of NH3 and H2O desorption maxima in NH3/H2O-OPTPD profiles and a similarity of the profiles, may indicate desorption of ammonia and water to lead to the destruction of the surface compounds containing both components. The higher retention capacity of H2O for the systems with MgO:SiO2 ratio of (3:1) and (1:1) is likely to be caused by the interaction of water vapor with MgO, and not just acid sites of the catalyst surface. Moreover, for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) sample, a significant amount of H2O desorbed at the temperatures above 648 K may be resulted from H2O adsorption on LAS [Mg-O-Si] and [Zn-O-Si]. To investigate the effect of competitive adsorption of water and reagents/reaction products on active sites of the catalyst surface, adsorption/desorption experiments of CO2 was performed after H2O pre-adsorption. Fig. 7 presents CO2/H2O-OPTPD profiles of the studied two- (ZnO/MgO, ZnO/SiO2) and three- (ZnO/MgO-SiO2) component catalytic systems. The hydrated surface of ZnO/MgO is characterized by the highest retention capacity of CO2 (Table 4 ), as with the OPTPD experiments without H2O pre-adsorption (Table 3). Therefore, both dehydrated and hydrated magnesium oxide in the catalyst composition is characterized by a sufficiently high basicity. The difference in the values of activation energy for CO2 desorption from the base sites in the cases of CO2-OPTPD and CO2/H2O-OPTPD may be due to the presence of BBS on the hydrated surface of ZnO/MgO catalyst. Meanwhile, ZnO/MgO sample after H2O pre-adsorption is also characterized by the highest water retention capacity. The hydrated surface of ZnO/SiO2 is characterized by the lowest retention capacity of CO2, while the water retention capacity is a quarter of that for ZnO/MgO. H2O molecules are suggested to chemisorb on the acid sites [Zn-O-Si] and on silica itself. The retention capacity of CO2 for ZnO/MgO-SiO2(1:1) sample is five times lower than for ZnO/MgO, while the water retention capacity is lower by almost one quarter. In the ZnO/MgO-SiO2 (1:1) sample a significant portion of magnesium oxide is evidenced to interact with silica to form acid sites [Mg-O-Si], and as a result, the portion of strong base sites of the hydrated surface decreases. FTIR spectra of adsorbed CO2 after H2O pre-adsorption on ZnO/MgO-SiO2 (1:1) catalyst are shown in Fig. 8 . The absorption band at 1630 cm−1 can be attributed to chemisorbed H2O molecules, as proved by its presence in FTIR spectra of adsorbed H2O. The shoulder at 1660 cm−1 and the band at 1495 cm−1 are ascribed to bicarbonates formed on weakly basic OH groups of the catalyst surface [27,35,56], and the intensity of these bands decreases with an increase in temperature. The absorption bands at 1630 cm−1 can be attributed to asymmetric stretching vibrations of OCO of bidentate carbonate species which may be formed by the interaction of CO2 with intermediate strength Mg‒O pairs. However, the absence of the band at 1340−1320 cm−1 attributable to the asymmetric stretching OCO vibrations of bidentate carbonate species may reflect their hydration followed by the formation of bicarbonates. The presence of the bands at 1530 and 1420 cm−1 assigned to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of unidentate carbonates results from CO2 interaction with strong basic O2- anions of the catalyst surface. Therefore, there are Lewis and Brönsted base sites on the hydrated surface of the ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalyst. As known, a temperature of the maximum in the product desorption peak during temperature programmed surface reaction of ethanol over a catalyst is directly related to the strength of adsorbate-adsorbent interactions [57]. Comparing the intensities of the desorption profiles of ethanol conversion products in the presence of rectified ethanol and ethanol-water mixture allows one to estimate the effect of water vapor on the interaction of an ethanol molecule with the surface of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 (1:1). Fig. 9 shows the signals of the reagent and reaction products, namely H2, H2O, acetaldehyde, ethylene, ethanol, 1,3-butadiene, crotyl alcohol, crotonaldehyde, in the EtOH-TPSR over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 (1:1) in the presence of 96 vol% ethanol and ethanol-water mixture (80 vol% ethanol). The EtOH-TPSR curves have two regions with desorption maxima at 350−400 K and above 473 K, which was also observed for MgO-SiO2 [57], ZnO/MgO-SiO2 [30] та Zn–Y/beta [58] catalysts. The peaks in low-temperature region can be attributed to the products of dissociative adsorption of ethanol on highly active areas of the surface, and the peaks in high-temperature region can be attributed to the products of ethanol and acetaldehyde conversion adsorbed on less reactive sites of the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, there are some differences in intensity and shape of the product desorption curves in the presence of 96 vol% ethanol and the ethanol-water mixture. In the case of 96 vol% ethanol, there is one peak in low-temperature region with a maximum at 393 K on the water desorption curve. In the case of the ethanol-water mixture, a high-intensity peak with a maximum at 413 K and a shoulder at 373 K can be distinguished. The shoulder coincides with the first maximum on the deconvoluted H2O-OPTPD profile for this sample (Fig. 5). Therefore, the desorption of both water of the initial reaction mixture and that formed during the dehydration of ethanol to ethylene can concluded to occur at temperatures of 350−400 K. In high-temperature region of EtOH-TPSR curves in the presence of the ethanol-water mixture the intensity of desorption of unreacted ethanol is higher than that for 96 vol% ethanol, which is consistent with higher ethanol conversion value for 96 vol% ethanol (Fig. S4). Furthermore, in the case of 80 vol% ethanol the intensity of desorption of acetaldehyde is higher than that for 96 vol% ethanol, while the intensity of desorption of the CC coupling products (1,3-butadiene, crotyl alcohol) is lower. This may indicate that water blocks active sites of CC coupling reaction of acetaldehyde. The tendencies of change in the intensity of desorption of water and ethylene + BD are similar, and thus the desorption of water formed in the reactions of ethanol and crotyl alcohol dehydration is assumed to be preferable in the temperature range above 473 K. It should be noted that the intensity of ethylene desorption during EtOH-TPSR is insignificantly higher in the case of ethanol-water mixture used as the feed than in the case of 96 vol% ethanol. Furthermore, in the case of ethanol-water mixture the signal of crotyl alcohol is low enough. This may indicate the modification of active surface sites by water molecules with in situ formation of acid sites (for example, partial transformation of Lewis acid sites into Brönsted ones [14]), on which the dehydrogenation reaction is carried out rather than aldol condensation. This assumption is consistent with the mentioned change of acetaldehyde desorption intensity with the change of 96 vol% ethanol to the ethanol-water mixture. By comparing desorption intensities of the products of CC coupling reactions during EtOH-TPSR and isopropanol-TPSR, the maxima of the formation of the CC coupling products are noted to be comparable. Therefore, the active sites of similar nature are needed to carry out CC coupling reaction of various carbonyl compounds formed from alcohol (ethanol, isopropanol). The results obtained indicate that the hydrophilic properties of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 are determined by the MgO:SiO2 ratio, and the chemisorption of water occurs preferably on Mg-containing sites. A symbatic change in acidity of the catalysts with their hydrophilicity is observed. The presence of water in the ethanol feed (or ethanol-water mixture) leads, first of all, to a decrease in the formation of CC coupling products, probably due to the competing adsorption of water vapor on active sites of aldol condensation of acetaldehyde. It is also possible to transform a part of surface active sites (of ethanol conversion), in particular, Lewis acid sites into Brönsted ones. It is assumed that active sites on the hydrated surface of individual magnesium oxide are practically inactive in CC coupling reaction, and hydrated sites formed with the participation of magnesium and silicon oxides remain active in CC coupling reaction even in the presence of water in the reaction mixture. 4 Conclusions Three-component oxide samples of ZnO/MgO–SiO2 with various MgO:SiO2 ratios (1:1–3:1), also ZnO/MgO and ZnO/SiO2 were characterized as catalysts for the conversion of aqueous ethanol into 1,3-butadiene. Acid-base properties of the samples were evaluated by one-pass temperature-programmed desorption (OPTPD) of CO2 and NH3 controlled by time-of-flight mass spectrometry and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine. ZnO/MgO is characterized by the highest basicity; the number of medium and strong base sites of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 system decreases as the MgO content decreases. On the surface of two- and three-component catalytic systems there are Lewis acid sites of various nature: [Zn-O-Si], [Mg-O-Si] and weak acid sites of magnesium oxide (Mg2+). Based on the OPTPD data of CO2 and NH3 after the probe molecule adsorption on the hydrated catalyst surface, it is qualitatively shown that the water adsorption leads to a change in the acid-base characteristics of the surface. To evaluate water vapor effect on functional properties of the catalyst, water vapor adsorption/desorption over the surface, temperature programmed surface reaction of ethanol and isopropanol conversion reaction in the absence/presence of water vapor in the feed were performed. The results obtained indicate that the hydrophilicity of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 is determined by the MgO:SiO2 ratio, and the chemisorption of water occurs preferably on Mg-containing sites with the formation of Brönsted base sites. The presence of water in the initial reaction mixture leads to a decrease in the formation of CC coupling products, probably due to the adsorption of water vapor on active sites of aldol condensation of acetaldehyde. The hydrated sites formed in the interface of magnesia and silica remain active in CC coupling reaction even in the presence of water in the reaction mixture. The selectivity of BD formation > 60 % is achieved in the conversion of ethanol-water mixture (80 vol% ethanol) in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts with the ratio of MgO:SiO2 = (1:1) and (3:1). coredata.dc:description: A series of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 systems have been prepared and characterized by one-pass temperature-programmed desorption of CO2, NH3 and H2O, FTIR spectroscopy with adsorbed pyridine and CO2, temperature programmed surface reaction of ethanol and isopropanol, and reaction of isopropanol conversion. Effect of MgO:SiO2 ratio in the catalysts on catalytic performance in 1,3-butadiene production from aqueous ethanol have been investigated. The results indicate that hydrophilicity of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 are determined by MgO:SiO2 ratio, and chemisorption of water occurs preferably on Mg-containing sites. The presence of water in the initial ethanol leads to a decrease in formation of the CC coupling products. The hydrated sites formed in the interface of magnesia and silica remain active in the CC coupling reaction even in the presence of water. 1,3-Butadiene selectivity >60 % in the conversion of aqueous ethanol (80 vol%) is achieved in the presence of ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts with the ratio of MgO:SiO2 = (1:1) and (3:1).
coredata.dc:title: 1,3-Butadiene production from aqueous ethanol over ZnO/MgO-SiO2 catalysts: Insight into H2O effect on catalytic performance
